prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Imaging the dust emission with high angular resolution at band 7

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our main goal is to image the dust continuum emission of a transitional disk. Thanks to the great sensitivity of ALMA, the requested sensitivity can be achieved with just a few minutes of observing time on source. Due to the calibration overheads, using four basebands to observe the continuum emission or just one makes almost no difference in the total observing time. Therefore, we plan to use one baseband for the continuum and to tune the other three basebands to the molecular line transitions CO (3-2), 13CO (3-2), CS (7-6), H13CN (4-3) and SO2 (11(6,6)-12(5,7)). We have chosen a bandwidth of 468.75 MHz and a spectral resolution of ~0.4 km/s for these three basebands. We have also averaged some channels to reduce the data rate. The detection of these lines is not guaranteed, but we will be able to improve the SNR by integrating the emission over all the expected linewidth (~3 km/s). The resulting aggregate bandwidth is ~4.7 GHz, which results in a difference of just ~5 minute of total observing time in comparison with the observing time we would need if we used the maximum bandwidth of 7.5 GHz.

We want to image at very high angular resolution the dust continuum emission of a protoplanetary disk with an inner cavity of radius 0.19, an annular gap from 0.28 to 0.48, and a protoplanet candidate that falls in the middle of the annular gap. As shown by our simulations (see scientific justification), with an angular resolution of 0.09 we will be able to completely resolve all these substructures and disentangle the circumplanetary emission from the edges of the gap. Thanks to the great sensitivity of ALMA, we will also be able to use uniform weighting to obtain images with even a better angular resolution without compromising the detection of the disk emission.
The expected angular size of the molecular line emission is ~3 (from Raman et al. 2006). The dust emission is expected to be more compact. Thus, we are asking for a maximum angular scale of 4.

We want to image the dust continuum emission of a transitional disk with an inner disk, multiple gaps and a protoplanet candidate that falls in the middle of one of these gaps. According to our model (see scientific justification), with a sensitivity of 0.1 mJy/beam at band 7 we will be able to detect with a SNR>5 all these structures, even the inner disk. Thanks to the great sensitivity of ALMA, this sensitivity can be achieved with just a few minutes of observing time on source.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Imaging the molecular emission at band 6 (CO (2-1))

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We plan to observe CO (2-1), 13CO (2-1) and C18O (2-1) lines with a spectral resolution of ~0.19 km/s. We expect a total line width of ~3km/s (from Panic et al. 2008), so this spectral resolution will be enough to resolve and study the kinematics of the system. We request a spectral resolution of ~0.09 km/s for these lines and will average the channels during the analysis of the data to get the requested sensitivity. We will be able to observe these three lines with just two basebands. We plan to observe the continuum emission with a higher angular resolution as a different science goal. Thus, we will tune the other two basebands of the correlator at the SiO (nu=0 5-4), SO2 (nu=0 16(6,10)-17(5,13)) and SO2 (nu=0 4(2,2)-3(1,3)) lines at no extra cost of observing time. We have chosen a bandwidth of 234.375 MHz for the SO2 lines and 468.75 MHz for the SiO line, with a spectral resolution of ~0.3 km/s for the three lines. We have also averaged some channels in order to reduce the data rate. In this way, we will be able to use the line free channels to improve the continuum observation of the previously mentioned band 6 science goal.

We want to image the line emission of a protoplanetary disk of ~3 size with an inner cavity of 0.38 size. Our goal is to study the kinematical and density distribution of the gas throughout the disk and, specially, inside the inner cavity of the gap. Thus, we request an angular resolution of 0.2, which will allow us to resolve the disk and even its inner cavity.
As mentioned above, the expected angular size of the molecular line emission is ~3 (from Raman et al. 2006). Thus, we are asking for a maximum angular scale of 4.

We want to image the 13CO (2-1) line emission of the transitional disk around HD 169142. Panic et al (2008) performed 13CO (2-1) observations towards this disk with the SMA. Correcting for our much smaller beam, we estimate from their observations an intensity of 30mJy/beam for the 13CO (2-1) line in the inner regions of the disk. In order to properly study this emission we are requesting a sensitivity of 3mJy/beam in a channel of 0.19 km/s, which will give us a signal to noise ratio of 10. We will have even a better detection of the CO (2-1) line thanks to its much higher brightness. Since the C18O (2-1) line falls within the same baseband as the 13CO (2-1) line, we will get this line at no extra cost in observing time. We expect to have an approximately 3-sigma detection of the C18O (2-1) line in a channel of 0.19 km/s. We will be able to improve the SNR of this detection by averaging some spectral channels during the data analysis. We also note that by integrating the emission over all the linewidth, which will be needed to estimate the density distribution of the gas, the detection of the three lines will be even better.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Imaging the dust emission at band 4

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our main goal is to detect the continuum emission. Thus, we plan to use the total bandwidth available of 7.5GHz. However, we have set up strategically the four basebands to allow the serendipitous detection of the CS(3-2) and C34S(3-2) transitions. We have chosen a spectral resolution for the two basebands tuned at these lines of ~2km/s, in order to help the possible detection without decreasing the total bandwidth and, thus, compromising the con+tinuum sensitivity. We have also had to average some channels to reduce the data rate.

We want to image the dust continuum emission of a protoplanetary disk with an inner cavity of 0.19 radius, an annular gap from 0.28 to 0.48, and a protoplanet candidate that falls in the middle of the second gap. As shown by our simulations (see scientific justification), with an angular resolution of 0.2 we will be able to resolve all these substructures. Thanks to the great sensitivity of ALMA, we will also be able to use uniform weighting to obtain images with even a better angular resolution without compromising the detection of the disk emission.
The expected angular size of the molecular line emission is ~3 (from Raman et al. 2006). The dust emission is expected to be more compact. Thus, we are asking for a maximum angular scale of 4.

We plan to image the dust continuum emission of a transitional disk with an inner disk, multiple gaps and a protoplanet candidate that falls in the middle of one of these gaps. We want to detect the continuum emission up to a radius of ~125 AU, in order to fully characterize its density structure. According to our model (see scientific justification), the disk will have an intensity of approximately 0.1 mJy/beam at this radius. Therefore, we are requesting for a sensitivity of 0.025 mJy/beam in order to reach a signal to noise ratio of 4.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Imaging the dust emission with high angular resolution at band 6

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We want to image the dust continuum emission of a transitional disk. Thanks to the great sensitivity of ALMA, the requested sensitivity can be achieved with just a few minutes of observing time on source. Due to the calibration overheads, using four basebands to observe the continuum emission or just two makes almost no difference in the total observing time. Therefore, we plan to use two basebands for the continuum and to tune the other two basebands so that the molecular line transitions CO (2-1), 13CO (2-1) and C180 (2-1) can be observed. We have chosen a spectral resolution of ~0.3 km/s for the three lines and averaged some channels to reduce the data rate. The detection of these lines is not guaranteed. However, we note that we are also requesting (as a different science goal) lower angular resolution observations of these same molecular lines. Therefore, by combining the data of both observations we may be able to improve the angular resolution of, at least, the integrated emission maps of the other science goal. The resulting aggregate bandwidth of our proposed setup is ~4.7 GHz, which results in a difference of just ~10 minutes of total observing time to the needed time if we used the maximum bandwidth of 7.5 GHz.

We want to image the dust continuum emission of a protoplanetary disk with an inner cavity of radius 0.19, an annular gap from 0.28 to 0.48, and a protoplanet candidate that falls in the middle of the second gap. As shown by our simulations (see scientific justification), with an angular resolution of 0.12 we will be able to resolve all these substructures and disentangle the circumplanetary emission from the edges of the gap.. Thanks to the great sensitivity of ALMA, we will also be able to use uniform weighting to obtain images with even a better angular resolution without compromising the detection of the disk emission.
The expected angular size of the molecular line emission is ~3 (from Raman et al. 2006). The dust emission is expected to be more compact. Thus, we are asking for a maximum angular scale of 4.

We want to image the dust continuum emission of a transitional disk with an inner disk, multiple gaps and a protoplanet candidate that falls in the middle of one of these gaps. According to our model (see scientific justification), with a sensitivity of 0.04 mJy/beam at band 6 we will be able to detect with a SNR>5 all these structures, even the inner disk. Thanks to the great sensitivity of ALMA, this sensitivity can be achieved with just a few minutes of observing time on source.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Our recent very high angular resolution (0.1-0.2 arcsec) VLA observations of the 7 mm dust emission, together with a very detailed modeling, have revealed the HD 169142 pre-transitional disk as a unique target to test planet formation theories. The disk presents at least two gaps in the dust distribution, each containing an identified protoplanet candidate. We fitted the SED and the radial intensity profile using a physically self-consistent model that predicts settling of large dust grains near the equatorial plane and near the outer walls of the gaps. We propose ALMA observations in bands 4, 6, and 7 with the following goals: (i) to characterize the dust grain size distribution throughout the disk; (ii) to confirm the presence of circumplanetary dust, (iii) to search for other gaps and possible protoplanets; (iv) to obtain the disk kinematics; and (v) to detect directly the residual central disk that should characterize pre-transitional disks.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.01012.S, Characterizing Planet Formation in the Pre-Transitional Disk of HD 169142, Mayra Osorio
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Centro de Radioastronomia y Astrofisica, Universidad Nacional Autonomo de Mexico
